channel.title: benbutchart Tour Blog
channel.description: A Guided Tour Blog Powered By Edinburgh Cityscope

wp:category.wp:category_description: This category is used to tag post that comprise your tour. Go ahead and change the Name to something that represents your theme - "Edinburgh's Architecture". But don't change the slug unless you really know what you're doing - otherwise the app might not be able to access your tour.

But don't change the slug unless you really know what you're doing - otherwise the app might not be able to access your tour.

item.title: Acknowledgements
item.dc:creator: nosborn2
item.content:encoded: This project is funded by AHRC, a University of Edinburgh Innovation Initiative Grant (IIG), and Science, Technology and Innovation Studies (STIS) of the School of Social and Political Science. We would like to thank the following individuals and organisations for their invaluable help with this project: John Henry, for providing much invaluable information and advice, for kindly agreeing to let us use video recordings of his final history of science walking tour and for coming up with the idea in the first place. Morna Findlay, James Loxley, Richard Roger, Jonathan Silvertown and our other partners at Edinburgh Cityscope. Daisy Cunynghame and Iain Milne of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh. Anna Downie of the Museum of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh. Graeme Herbert of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Klaus Staubermann and Geoff Swinney of the National Museums of Scotland. Chris Speed of Edinburgh College of Art. Thomas Ahnert, Bill Aird, Dominic Berry, Lawrence Dritsas, Julian Goodare, Miguel Garcia-Sancho, Anna Groundwater, Zubin Mistry, Dmitriy Myelnikov, Alasdair Raffe, Richard Rogers, Rick Sowerby, Jo Spiller, Steve Sturdy, Matjaz Vidmar, all historians of science and medicine of the University of Edinburgh who generously shared their knowledge with us. Augustus Veinoglou, Agis Theodoropoulos and Karen Forbes for their helpful discussions with Niki Vermeulen. Cate Sutton for her design work. Nicola Osborne, Ben Butchart and Ian Fieldhouse of EDINA, whose technical wizardry made this project possible. Amy Woodgate, University of Edinburgh MOOCs Project Manager, for help with editing the video. Full information on all images used on this site and in the Curious Edinburgh app are listed on our Image Credits page

item.title: Download the Curious Edinburgh App
item.dc:creator: nosborn2
item.content:encoded:
The Curious Edinburgh mobile app will help you explore the rich history of scientific discovery and practice in Edinburgh, and it's free to download ! Download a copy to your iPhone or iPad (running iOS 8 or later), try it out, and do let us know what you think – rate or review us on the App Store or get in touch with team through the comments here, or by email. The app is currently iOS only but if you are interested in an Android version do let us know and we'll get in touch with any updates. How to Use the App
  1. Download and install the app from the App Store.
  2. Tap on the Curious Edinburgh app icon to open up the app and start exploring!
  3. Explore a Map of the History of Science Tour, which takes you around some of the most notable moments in Edinburgh's scientific heritage as well as some of the most beautiful parts of the city. You can follow the tour in any order but we've suggested a route that you'll find on the map.
  4. Click on numbered tour stops to view more information, tap on images and videos to view in more detail.
  5. Alternatively: explore the List view to see all of the tour stops at once. Tap on a tour stop for more information, images and video.
  6. Enjoy exploring the app and the city!
We would love to hear your comments on the app, the tour, and your suggestions for improvements in the future. To find out more about the Curious Edinburgh project, the team behind the app, and our wonderful partners, supporters and funders, take a look at our acknowledgements page.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: benbutchart
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Old College, University of Edinburgh
item.dc:creator: xbillhjenkins
item.content:encoded:
South Bridge, Edinburgh EH8 9YL

The University of Edinburgh was first established on this site in 1582. Unusually, it was founded by the town council of Edinburgh and most of its professorial chairs remained in the gift of the  council until the reforms brought in by the Universities (Scotland) Act in 1858. Work on the building we see now was started in 1789 and it was more or less completed by 1827. The original design was by Robert Adam. Adam died in 1792 and the building was completed by William Henry Playfair. The dome was only added in 1887. With the exception of the Talbot Rice Gallery, the interiors of the University buildings are not open to the public. [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i64wvdnHSIw[/embed]

The University of Edinburgh was first established on this site in 1582. Unusually, it was founded by the town council of Edinburgh and most of its professorial chairs remained in the gift of the council until the reforms brought in by the Universities (Scotland) Act in 1858. Work on the building we see now was started in 1789 and it was more or less completed by 1827. The original design was by Robert Adam. Adam died in 1792 and the building was completed by William Henry Playfair. The dome was only added in 1887.
With the exception of the Talbot Rice Gallery, the interiors of the University buildings are not open to the public.
The University of Edinburgh was first established on this site in 1582.

item.title: Surgeon's Hall Museums
item.dc:creator: xbillhjenkins
item.content:encoded:
Nicolson St, Edinburgh EH8 9BZ The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh was founded in 1505. Its Museum began to amass anatomical specimens in 1699 and it grew rapidly in the 19th century through the donations of the collections of the famous Edinburgh anatomists Sir Charles Bell and John Barclay. Perhaps the museum's most famous curator was Robert Knox, who worked here from 1825 until 1831, when  enemies within the College used his association with the murders committed by Burke and Hare to force his resignation. Today the museum is open to the public for a small fee. [caption id="attachment_294" align="alignnone" width="240"] Robert Knox (1791–1862).[/caption] [caption id="attachment_295" align="alignnone" width="240"] Surgeons' Hall, 1890.[/caption] Find out more
  • Surgeons’ Hall Museum

The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh was founded in 1505. Its Museum began to amass anatomical specimens in 1699 and it grew rapidly in the 19th century through the donations of the collections of the famous Edinburgh anatomists Sir Charles Bell and John Barclay. Perhaps the museum's most famous curator was Robert Knox, who worked here from 1825 until 1831, when enemies within the College used his association with the murders committed by Burke and Hare to force his resignation. Today the museum is open to the public for a small fee.
The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh was founded in 1505.

item.title: My Tour Map Page
item.dc:creator: benbutchart
item.content:encoded: Use the + and - signs to zoom in and out of the map. Click on the map pins to view the tour stop. [osm_map_v3 map_center="55.949,-3.195" zoom="12" width="98%" height="100%" tagged_type="post" tagged_filter="My Tour" marker_name="mic_blue_pinother_02.png"]

item.title: My Tour Home Page
item.dc:creator: benbutchart
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to your personal Guided Tour blog, powered by Edinburgh Cityscope. This is the landing page for your guided tour. On this page , you will probably want to show a list of stops on your tour (which at the moment will be any post you have tagged with the category "My Tour")
  1. Surgeon's Hall Museums The Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh was founded in 1505. Its Museum began to amass anatomical
  2. Old College, University of Edinburgh The University of Edinburgh was first established on this site in 1582. Unusually, it was founded by the town council of Edinburgh
  3. The two example posts are listed above. You should add links to your own posts here.
  Each post you add, tagged with the category "My Tour" will be used by the Curious Edinburgh app. You should use the custom fields at the bottom of the post to provide information such as longitude and latitude, and the stop number.
